Award.AwardTitle: Student Program of the Second Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AI), Ethics and Society (AIES 2019)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the participation of a select group of US-based Ph. D. students in the student program of the Second AAAI/ACM Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Ethics and Society (AIES 2019) which will take place in Honolulu, HI on January 27th and 28th, 2019.

AIES was formed to promote concrete planning and research in the present and future of AI, examining the imperative that technologists talk not only to one another, but to thinkers and experts across the humanities and social sciences as well. The AIES conference is a valuable opportunity for students from a range of disciplines to learn from AI experts across the disciplinary spectrum including computer scientists, sociologists, philosophers, economists, and lawyers specializing in privacy, human rights, and other relevant aspects of law. This exposure will help enrich their understanding of the powers and perils of their own work. The student track also serves as an important opportunity for "cohort-building" among students in various humanities and social science disciplines, with disparate knowledge bases and trainings but a common concern for the future of AI.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF conference grant supported the participation of a select group of US-based Ph.D. students to the student program of the Second AAAI/ACM Conference on AI, Ethics and Society (AIES 2019) which took place in Honolulu, HI on January 27th and 28th, 2019 (http://www.aies-conference.com/student-program/). Increasingly, artificial intelligence plays a role in the basic conditions of human life. In order to think concretely and responsibly about the present and future of AI, it is imperative that technologists talk not only to one another, but also to thinkers and experts across the humanities and social sciences. AIES was founded two years ago to fill this need, and the inaugural meeting, held in February 2018 in New Orleans, LA, was a resounding success. A crucial part of this conference is the student track, which offers students an ?on-ramp? into the conference.  As in the previous edition, this year?s student track motivating experience offered structured opportunities to interact with the interdisciplinary group of scholars who attended AIES.

 

The AIES 2019 student program was very successful. It received a total of 33 submissions from students from 6 different countries with a predominant participation of US students. All submissions received 2 reviews from members of the program committee and 24 were accepted.  The authors of the accepted papers received a free registration and a travel grant. All of the US citizens or permanent residents were supported from this grant. Moreover, the accepted students presented a poster, met senior members of the community and representatives of the sponsoring companies on a one-on-one basis, participated to a student lunch and had the opportunity to publish a 2-page extended abstract of their work in the proceedings.

 

Intellectual Merit.  This year AIES has once again confirmed itself as a valuable opportunity for students from a range of disciplines to learn from AI experts across the disciplinary spectrum: not only other CS scholars, but also sociologists, philosophers, economists, and lawyers specializing in privacy, human rights, and other relevant aspects of law. The exposure enriched their understanding of the powers and perils of their own work.  The student track also served as an important opportunity for ?cohort-building? among participants. In addition to CS students, a small group of highly engaged students from the humanities and social science disciplines participated and brought a different perspective to the discussion. The AIES 2019 student program served as an opportunity to connect these students to one another, as well as to the conference as a whole, fostering the potential for both collaborative research among participants and for solo research by individual participants that is deeply informed by sustained conversation with the colleagues whom they have met at AIES.

 

Broader Impact: Interdisciplinary work on AI is crucial to ensure that both new and existing technologies are used in a way that promotes individual and social well-being, and that new technologies alleviate structural injustices rather than compound them. Interdisciplinary conferences on this topic have the potential to transform the future of AI, both by creating a forum for interdisciplinary analysis and by connecting technologists to scholars of sociology, philosophy, political science, law and other related disciplines.  As valuable as these interdisciplinary spaces may be for current professionals, they are even more valuable for students, who are still in the process of learning about what is expected of, and what is possible for, a professional in the field. Conferences like this AIES provide an invaluable model for scholars-in-the-making. In this year?s edition, not only did the conference expose them to current work across a range of disciplines: it also provided them with a model for what interdisciplinary scholarship can look like. The interaction with leading experts in diverse and yet complementary disciplines contributed in forming a cohort of students who will play a crucial role in the international community of scholars.

The range of topics to which they were exposed at AIES 2019 will prepare them to participate to the advancement of science and high-tech industry in the US while being mindful of core issues like user privacy, algorithmic bias, and the role of technology in mediating the attention economy. The program attracted a diverse participation  in terms of disciplines, gender, ethnic background and academic institution.
